title: Understanding Preload in Web Performance
content: What is the purpose of using `<link rel="preload">` in a web application?

options.text: To load critical resources earlier for faster interactivity
To defer resource loading until needed
To lazy load components on user interaction

explanation: Preload helps load critical resources early to improve metrics like Time to Interactive or First Input Delay.
sampleAnswers: Preload ensures critical assets are downloaded earlier, speeding up interactivity.

title: Preload vs Prefetch
content: What is the main difference between preloading and prefetching resources?

options.text: Preload is for resources needed immediately, prefetch is for resources needed soon
Prefetch loads higher priority resources than preload
Preload is always handled automatically by the browser

explanation: Preload prioritizes resources needed right away; prefetch prepares resources for potential future use.
sampleAnswers: Preload fetches resources needed instantly, while prefetch prepares for later needs.

title: Webpack Preload Magic Comment
content: What does adding `/* webpackPreload: true */` to a dynamic import do?

options.text: It bundles the module into the main chunk
It adds a `<link rel='preload'>` tag for that chunk
It delays loading of the module until user interaction

explanation: The magic comment tells Webpack to emit a preload link for that resource, so the browser fetches it immediately.
sampleAnswers: It signals Webpack to preload that module so it’s available on initial render.

title: Trade-offs of Using Preload
content: What is a potential downside of preloading too many resources?

options.text: It can delay critical rendering paths like CSS and hero images
It causes the browser to ignore other preload hints
It disables the browser cache for those resources

explanation: Preloading too many assets can block more important ones, increasing First Contentful Paint time.
sampleAnswers: Too many preloads can block essential resources and harm performance.

title: Preload in Single-Page Applications
content: In SPAs, when is preloading most useful?
explanation: Preloading helps ensure components needed immediately after page load are ready without waiting for network fetches.
sampleAnswers: When a component or font must be available instantly on the first render.

title: Preload + Async Hack
content: What is the goal of combining `<link rel='preload'>` with `<script async>`?

options.text: To load a script early without blocking the HTML parser
To delay the script until the user interacts

explanation: This technique downloads the script as a high-priority resource but doesn’t block parsing while it loads.
sampleAnswers: It lets browsers fetch scripts early without blocking page rendering.

title: Preload in Chrome 95+
content: How did Chrome 95+ improve the safety of using preload?
explanation: Chrome 95+ fixed queue-jumping behavior, making preload order more predictable relative to other resources.
sampleAnswers: It made preload ordering more consistent and less likely to block critical resources.

title: Best Practices for Using Preload
content: Which of the following is a recommended best practice when using preload?

options.text: Use preload sparingly and measure its impact in production
Preload all JavaScript files to reduce bundle size
Always preload images before any CSS files

explanation: Preload should only be used for critical resources and its performance impact should be measured carefully.
sampleAnswers: Use preload only for critical assets and monitor performance impact.
